awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Next Generation Residential Solar Power
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is a residential solar power generation technology that could provide a significant improvement to the United States and world goals to reduce carbon emissions. This project combines several breakthrough technology developments to make solar-generated electricity practical for the consumer, installer, and the power company.  The breakthroughs are not in photovoltaic (PV) efficiency, but instead, focus on technology that significantly increases dependability (reliability, accessibility, and maintainability); makes installations easier; and makes residential solar energy suitable for large-scale power generation for utility companies. The target customers are regional companies that sell and install solar energy systems on residential rooftops. These companies are sensitive to the reliability (warranty), affordability, performance, and safety of the equipment that they install. There are about 1,000 solar power installation companies in the US, and they are outfitting homes at the combined rate of almost one per minute. The solar energy market is currently valued at $17 billion dollars annually and is expected to double in size in the next 5 years.

This STTR Phase I project proposes to develop an innovative architecture that consists of modular PV panels, unique non-flammable battery packs, patent-pending high efficiency converters, and a sophisticated interface to utility grids. There are no power combiners, external charging systems, communications boxes, current transformers, load switches, sub-panels, inverter boxes, power optimizers, or bulky battery packs involved. The product provides a much-needed breakthrough for the utility industry as it enables residential solar power generation to be a suitable power source for large-scale connection to existing power grids.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

Residential solar power generation could provide a significant contribution to US and world-wide goals to reduce carbon emissions. But residential solar is falling short of its potential, because the implementation reflects its technical heritage. In this STTR project, the team of Protium Power Systems, Inc. (PPS) and the University of Central Florida (UCF) designed, developed, prototyped, and tested SmartPowerTM, which combines several breakthrough technology developments to make solar-generated electricity practical for the consumer, installer, and the power company. The breakthroughs are not in PV efficiency. They are in technology that is affordable for the consumer, makes it much easier for the installer, and makes residential solar acceptable to utility companies.

SmartPowerTM uses an innovative patentable architecture. Phase I demonstrated that the innovative architecture could be implemented.

Broader Impact:

Residential solar power was born with the assembly of disparate and discrete components from individual manufacturers. There was poor efficiency and no energy storage. The next generation of solar power brought improved energy conversion technologies, and storage batteries, but it was very expensive. The Return-on-Investment (ROI) has typically been 15 to 20 years.

SmartPowerTM has the potential to impact the industry, by making the consumer's ROI for residential solar power generation attractive for the average homeowner. ROIs of less than 5 years are practical with SmartPowerTM. Massive adoption of residential solar power will impact the nation’s power generation, transmission, and distribution favorably.

A classic technology progression is to start with centralized resources, and migrate to decentralized resources as the technology improves. For example, the original computers were time-shared monsters housed in computer rooms. Today there are computers on desktops, in our pockets, and on our wrists. SmartPowerTM takes the important step of decentralizing power generation by making the generation system practical and affordable.


Last Modified: 06/24/2024
Modified by: Russell L Case
